text: Last night on MasterChef Australia.
- Who's hungry? - Me!
Two teams faced their toughest critics
when they catered for 150 guests at a children's birthday party.
- They're loving them. - It's all good.
A massive 93 votes saw the blue team take victory and the reward.
Now go and have lunch at Sails on Lavender Bay.
But on the red team, low vote for Adele and Jonathan put them both up for elimination.
I'm not ready to go home. Not at all.
Tonight, they both face a challenge unlike any seen before.
What's in this pot holds the key to your future in this competition.
It will put their imagination and skill to the test.
I'm feeling really, really nervous.
And for one of them the dream will end.
This is gonna make or break me in the MasterChef competition.
Jonathan, you scored one vote.
Adele, noone voted for your dish.
That means you both face the very real potential
of going home today.
I cooked sausage rolls for the children's party.
Unfortunately, it took a really long time for them to come out of the oven,
and the children didn't give me any points for my sausage rolls or my meatballs.
I'm not happy with myself that I'm going to the elimination round again.
Unfortunately, I only got one vote for my salmon blini.
Clearly not enough adults voted for it.
To the rest of the red team,
you're safe for today, please head upstairs.
We leave the kitchen. I mean, head up to the cafe to have a bit of a chat.
I'm not ready to go home, I want to be here a lot, lot longer,
and do a lot, lot more, and learn a lot, lot more.
My food dream is to own a beautiful cafe, where my son and I can cook together
and we can have some beautiful times.
My son Michael was born with dyspraxia. It's a language disorder.
Thing is, you've got to think about your boys.
So be strong for them, it's gonna turn your mind into a fighter.
We just work hard as, you know, as hard as you normally would and under no pressure.
I'm against you, Jonathan.
Last week I was in an elimination with Devon.
See you later, mate.
I made it through.
I think if I come through this I'll feel like some sort of eliminator.
The terminator in MasterChef kitchen.
It's not a good feeling.
The other side of it is you just have to do what you've gotta do I guess.
Yesterday was a team challenge.
We won, and we're off to lunch in one of Sydney's best resturants,
Sails in Lavender Bay.
Sydney Harbor, looking at the bridge, opera house, fine dining.
How good!
Cheers!
Good afternoon, welcome everybody. Congratulations.
Nathan Darling is the head chef at Sails and he comes out to announce the menu.
To start with I've got a beautiful little goat's cheese panna cotta
with fig, walnuts and vino cotto.
Beautiful.
We also have some lovely seared scallops with cucumber, apple and crispy onion salad.
Oh, I'm just loving this.
For mains we have lamb done two ways.
Oh, yum!
And John Dory.
We are having such a great lunch, but there's just this little thing
in the bottom of your stomach reminding you that someone in the losing team
is not going to be coming home.
Coming down the stairs with Jonathan and finding Matt Preston there,
I'm feeling really, really nervous.
Adele, Jonathan,
the challenge you're about to face is one that we've never done before
in the MasterChef kitchen.
Let's have a look at what this challenge involves.
Gary and George bringing this big pot, I'm thinking, what is in there?
It was a dead bird in there or something.
But God, they want me to skin it or something?
Adele, Jonathan, what's in this pot holds the key to your future
in this competition.
I'm feeling really, really nervous.
I'm up against Jonathan. I know I'm not safe.
Adele, Jonathan, let's see what's in the pot.
When they lift the lid of the pot, the smell was just foul, insipid, wrong.
It wasn't good.
Adele, any thoughts?
It's the beginning of something. A filling or...
A white bolognese?
You're both very close. It is a seriously flawed bolognese.
It's not a classic bolognese. It's not rich and unctuous.
And that's the challenge.
The challenge is to fix that dish.
You will each be given a portion of that sauce,
and you've gotta fix it.
You've gotta turn it into the most beautiful bolognese you can.
My first thought was, I don't wanna go against Adele on italian dish.
Adele is an italian mama. She's been cooking italian all her life.
It's still daunting. I mean, just because I'm italian...
everybody can cook a really good bolognese.
And I'm up against Jonathan.
To fix that bad bolognese, you're gonna need additional ingredients.
And these are the ingredients that we have.
Vegetables.
A selection of meats.
Herbs and seasonings.
You also get to choose from liquids and oils.
The next selection is dairy.
You also get to choose from some miscellaneous items
and a couple of odd ones, that include anchovies, chocolate and vegemite.
Jonathan, Adele, here are the rules. You have ten steps
to fix that dish.
You can use one ingredient per step.
Once you've used an ingredient, you cannot use that ingredient again.
Right, guys, you've got your sauce, you know the rules,
it's time to fix that dish.
Off to your stations.
Adele, your chance to fix that dish starts now.
The first step is, I want to put some flavor into it.
And the only way you can do that is putting some sort of meat,
like bacon or pancetta, or something in there.
I wanna fry up the pancetta, and just get all the flavors coming out of it.
Jonathan, it's your turn to take your first step. Let's go.
My plan is to add ingredients that I would normally have in a bolognese.
To cook it separately, and then keep adding it,
so it comes to the point where it's about evenly cooked.
And then add some grated carrot, I'm gonna fry off this.
Because there's no real flavor in the bolognese,
I'm gonna brown the carrot to try and get some caramelization flavor.
Out of the pot basically full of fluid I'm gonna keep using the fluid
to deglaze my pan. And eventually the fluid will be quite, quite reduced.
Jonathan, you've added your carrot and that little bit of reduced stock to your pot,
and Adele, we're going over to you for your second turn. Off you go.
- I drain off my meat... - Interesting.
... and I add it to my pancetta and start frying it off.
Because this beef needs to be browned up, it's gotta be caramelized,
and I've got a little bit of the oil from the pancetta which is gonna give it the flavor.
She's made a clever choice to actually fry it in the pan that she
cooked the pancetta in. So there's some lovely sugars coming out of the pancetta.
Jonathan, let's crack on.
I'm gonna get some garlic and fry off a little garlic.
Okay.
The main risk here is whether or not the garlic will be cooked out enough.
Cause taste of raw garlic in food is quite disgusting.
Adele, let's go. Your next turn.
I tasted my dish. It still lacks a lot of flavor.
She's taking garlic.
What's an Italian without lots of garlic?
This is what I do at home, so I'm feeling relaxed and confident about it.
My third step is to add celery. It really gives a nice flavor.
And I do the same thing with the celery that I did with the carrot.
Take out some of the moisture and then put it into the pan.
You know, one of the smart things that Jonathan's doing
is by deglazing the pan with that stock every time,
he's reducing the stock, he's intensifying the flavor all in one process.
That's smart thinking.
And I love that we've got this classic battle between the instinctive,
home cook, the italian mama versus this artist. Who's gonna come out on top?
My fourth step is I add chopped up tomatoes
which will start to give it that tomato taste.
I'm gonna return this back in here, and I'm gonna start cooking
my tomato in there.
My fourth step I've decided to use tinned tomatoes.
I'm not sure if this is the right decision. - Tinned tomatoes?
But I know if you use a lot of tinned tomatoes and you cook them down,
you're gonna get a really, really good flavor.
My fifth step I add tomato paste.
And what this is gonna do is richen it up for me a little bit more.
I think Adele's choice is very risky. Tomato paste needs to be cooked for a while.
You know, I never use concentrated tomato paste. So...
Never use tomato paste? Why is that?
It's good to be able to control the tomatoey flavor.
It can seem quite...
I don't know, kind of rough maybe.
I disagree.
I think, if you're cooking with tomato, you want the intense flavor,
and by the time I keep cooking this tomato,
I find I'm gonna have about forty minutes up my sleeve
that I've been cooking this tomato.
I don't agree.
I'm in my fifth step.
And at this point I'm gonna add chilli flakes.
Chilli.
Mate, you've got your chilli flakes, you put in what, about half a teaspoon there?
Yeah, probably about half teaspoon, yeah.
So, what I'm tryna do is, cause the tomato is quite acidic,
it will hit one part of your tongue, so I'm trying to make it like
chilli powder getdown, and you'll get a more rounded flavor in your mouth.
Look, guys, this could be the one ingredient that tips Jonathan's bolognese
out of contention of winning this competition.
This is gonna make or break me in the MasterChef competition.
If you're gonna go down, you make certain you go down well.
I'm gonna go down on fire.
The rules of this challenge are, we've got a pot of this bolognese,
that we've gotta fix. I've got ten steps, we can choose one ingredient per step.
I'm very anxious. I've got huge anxiety.
My sixth step is putting red wine.
Red wine just adds that little bit of robust flavor.
In my sixth step, I've also picked red wine, but I'm gonna reduce mine first.
Adele's put hers straight into the pot. I think that reducing it is important.
Wasn't expecting that.
Jonathan, I'd say that's a fairly high alcohol red wine.
That baby went up beautifully, didn't it? Look at that.
- In my face. - Yeah.
It's seventh step, and I add a little bit of salt to my dish.
- Now, Adele. - Yes?
That wouldn't be the last ingredient you'd choose?
Not for me. I really just wanna get the flavor now
so that I know what else it's gonna need.
My seventh step I pick black peppercorns.
Pepper. Black pepper.
I think he's floundering at the moment.
Everything he's put in is quite restrained in its flavor.
The next stage was sugar.
That tomato flavor was really strong, so I just want to cut the acidity
with the sugar.
My eighth step I also pick sugar.
The next step is I want to put cream in it just to round it off a bit,
just to soften it a little bit.
I just think a little bit of cream at the end of a bolognese is
just really nice. Just to lighten it.
So you're in a good and familiar place right now.
Yes.
Salt.
It's really hard to taste individual elements in the bolognese.
So salt is important because it's gonna determine the tenth ingredient that I put in.
So definitely needed salt.
Adele, Jonathan, you've now both got one step left.
Think about what you're gonna do. This could be the moment
that saves you or sends you home.
At this stage it's my final choice. And I just think,
well, I'll just put some grated cheese through it and that's it.
That's all I can really do to my sauce.
Jonathan.
You really need to make this last step count.
My final choice of ingredient is very difficult.
I wanted a fresh herb because I think that fresh herbs are really good through the sauce.
And I picked basil.
Smells good in here.
You've used some interesting techniques, some interesting ingredients,
it's gonna be fascinating for us to taste what you've cooked.
To see which dish is the best.
Guys, it's time for you to come down, you need to head on home.
We've watched the challenge unfold and now it's time for us to go downstairs and
say goodbye to them knowing that one of them is not coming back.
We've made good friendships in the house and so
it's upsetting saying goodbye to everyone,
thinking that this is the last time you're going to see them.
Bring up your dishes and let's taste.
So, taste time. Adele, you're first.
Fingers crossed.
I'm feeling really numb. My heart's...
I don't think it's even beating, and yeah, I'm feeling pretty
sick in my tummy.
Jonathan.
Waiting for the judges to tell us who's won is the most painful thing.
It's nerve wrecking.
Adele, Jonathan, we have a big decision to make here,
we're now going to deliberate.
Jonathan, Adele, we've tasted your dishes,
and we decided who's safe and who's going home.
Adele, you've taken a really bad bolognese
and turned it into something that's completely respectable.
It's got big flavors, really big smack of tomato,
what is unlike about it however, it's really harsh on the tomato.
It's started off a great little process there,
and you should have been a little bit more tender in terms of
how much of that tomato paste you put in,
cause that's what I get.
Jonathan.
What I do find in your dish is loads of complexity and flavors.
Every mouthful, different things pop up. Some celery, some carrot,
some sweetness, some bitterness, some heat.
Jonathan.
You've made it through. Adele, your MasterChef dream is over.
When I hear that I'm safe, this relief just fell all over me.
But it's not a victory. You've eliminated someone.
It feels like you failed again.
You just gotta take it, you gotta pick yourself up,
brush yourself off and start again.
Such a hard decision to make, but you're up against
I think, one of the best cooks in this competition.
We judge on the two dishes we taste, we judge on what happens on the day,
and today that dish didn't quite make it.
You've evolved as a cook, and today is the start
of a new beginning for you.
I've learned so much.
Never thought something like this would ever happen to me.
When you have dreams, you can make them happen, you've gotta give a dream a chance,
and you know, I did, I gave it my best shot,
and I think that's all you can ask of a person.
Adele, it's been an absolute pleasure having you in the MasterChef kitchen,
but unfortunately, your time is up.
- Thank you so much. - Thank you. Thank you, guys.
- Good luck, Adele. - Bye.
It's awful. It's awful. In a way, you just wanna run out back door.
Just get away. Just keep running.
But I am proud. And I am happy with who I am and what I've done.
There'd been a lot of speculation through the day that
who was gonna be cut loose today.
And, coming down the stairs, we see Dominic leading his team.
And we se that two people were not in the group.
- It's Adele. Adele and Jono. - Oh no.
So at this stage you guys don't know who's been eliminated?
No idea.
The light on the lift just moved. Someone's coming.
- Who is it? Who is it? - Jono.
It's just devastating for me,
because Adele and I have really been close since the beginning,
and we promised we'd look after each other.
And, I'm really sad that she's going home.
Man, for me, you've got my full respect, I thought you were amazing today.
Well done, man. Well done.
He really is the terminator, and you just don't wanna go up against him
in an elimination challenge.
The fact that he could take Adele out in a bolognese challenge,
it just goes to show you how absolutely and utterly strong Jonathan is.
This truly is a competition and I can't just ride in the middle of the pack.
I think I'm actually going to stay out of these eliminations.
Work my arse off.
It's definitely been the best thing I've ever, ever done for me.
It's something that I will never, ever forget.
Adele, we wanted to know, are you cooking dinner tonight?
I love making people happy with my food
and I really wanna keep continuing doing that
and hopefully maybe one day work with Michael, my son,
doing something together.
Tomorrow night on MasterChef Australia.
MasterClass is one of the best parts of the week.
Gary and George help you get the party started.
So, pay attention.
With some quick treats for the kids, and something a little more sophisticated
for the adults.
- Nice little adult treat. - I'll be there at that party for sure.
- Plus. - Welcome to Sake restaurant.
Executive chef Shaun Presland shows you how to make Japanese at home.
A lot of people try to overcomplicate making Japanese dishes,
it's incredibly easy to make.
